dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.cds.ctypes
Class Ptr<T extends CType>

java.lang.Object
  dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.cds.ctypes.CType
      dreisoft.tresos.generator.ng.api.cds.ctypes.Ptr<T>
Type Parameters:
T - generic type of the referenced c-type.

Copyright (C) Elektrobit Automotive GmbH - All rights reserved

Direct Known Subclasses:
PBPtr
public class Ptr<T extends CType>
extends CType

Represents a pointer in the C language. The generic type T shows the referenced class.

Since:
2008.b

Constructor Summary
Ptr(java.lang.String name, T reference)
          Creates a pointer to the given CType object with the given name.
Ptr(java.lang.String name, T refPrototype, T reference)
          Creates a pointer to the given CType object with the given name.
Ptr(T reference)
          Creates a pointer to the given CType object.
Ptr(T refPrototype, T reference)
          Creates a pointer to the given CType object and additionally defines a prototype of it.
 
Method Summary
 T getReference()
          Returns the reference of this pointer, can be null (null-pointer).
 T getRefPrototype()
          Returns the prototype of the referenced object, e.g. an UInt8 instance if this is a Pointer of uint8.
 void setReference(T reference)
          Changes the reference of this pointer, can be null (null-pointer).

Constructor Detail

Ptr

public Ptr(T reference)
Creates a pointer to the given CType object. This constructor does not define the name of the pointer so it is only for members of complex types (e.g. struct). To create a standalone pointer use constructor Ptr(String, CType) instead.

Parameters:
reference - The referenced object. Must not be null! To create a null-pointer see constructor Ptr(CType, CType).
Since:
2008.b

Ptr

public Ptr(T refPrototype,
           T reference)
Creates a pointer to the given CType object and additionally defines a prototype of it. This constructor is intended to create a null-pointer, otherwise constructor Ptr(CType) would be the better choice. It is necessary to know the referenced type so there must always be a prototype of the referenced object even if the reference itself is null. This constructor does not define the name of the pointer so it is only for members of complex types (e.g. struct). To create a standalone pointer use constructor Ptr(String, CType, CType) instead.

Parameters:
refPrototype - The prototype of the referenced object, never null.
reference - The referenced object. null means that this pointer points to null (a null-pointer), otherwise it should be the same object as the prototype.
Since:
2008.b

Ptr

public Ptr(java.lang.String name,
           T reference)
Creates a pointer to the given CType object with the given name. This constructor defines the name of the pointer so it is only for standalone use. If this pointer is a members of a complex type (e.g. struct or array) then it is not allowed to define the name explicitly and constructor Ptr(CType) must be used instead.

Parameters:
name - The name of this pointer.
reference - The referenced object. Must not be null! To create a null-pointer see constructor Ptr(String, CType, CType).
Since:
2008.b

Ptr

public Ptr(java.lang.String name,
           T refPrototype,
           T reference)
Creates a pointer to the given CType object with the given name. This constructor is intended to create a null-pointer, otherwise constructor Ptr(String, CType) would be the better choice. It is necessary to know the referenced type so there must always be a prototype of the referenced object even if the reference itself is null. This constructor defines the name of the pointer so it is only for standalone use. If this pointer is a members of a complex type (e.g. struct or array) then it is not allowed to define the name explicitly and constructor Ptr(CType) must be used instead.

Parameters:
name - The name of this pointer, never null.
refPrototype - refPrototype The prototype of the referenced object, never null.
reference - The referenced object. null means that this pointer points to null (a null-pointer), otherwise it should be the same object as the prototype.
Since:
2008.b
Method Detail

getReference

public T getReference()
Returns the reference of this pointer, can be null (null-pointer).

Returns:
The C-Type this pointer references to, or null.
Since:
2008.b

setReference

public void setReference(T reference)
Changes the reference of this pointer, can be null (null-pointer).

Parameters:
reference - The new reference of this pointer, maybe null.
Since:
2010.a

getRefPrototype

public T getRefPrototype()
Returns the prototype of the referenced object, e.g. an UInt8 instance if this is a Pointer of uint8.

Returns:
The prototype of the referenced object, never null
Since:
2008.b
